cleaned_text: Autism: Rough Draft Do you have children? Have you contemplated whether or not they should receive the childhood vaccine known as the MMR (measles, mumps and rubella) vaccine? As a parent you want to do what is best for your child/children. Parents make their decisions to the best of their abilities and knowledge. As the time goes on more and more parents are deciding not to have their children vaccinated because they believe that the MMR vaccine can cause the onset of autism spectrum disorder (ASD). For the safety of the general population, parents should have their children vaccinate because there is no link between the MMR vaccine and autism. (Children should receive their childhood vaccinations because there is no connection between them and the onset of autism. This is for the safety of both the child and general public.) Back in 1997 there was a wide spread fear that receiving the MMR vaccine increases the risk of autism. The theory originated from a study published by a British surgeon named Andrew Wakefield. He published an article inThe Lancet, a prestigious medical journal. His article suggested "that the measles, mumps, rubella (MMR) vaccine was increasing autism in British children" (Health Guide, 2018, p. 4). Wakefield's study took 12 children ranging from three to ten with the average age of 6. 11 of the children were boys. It was recorded in Andrew Wakefield's article that the 12 children started out with a history of normal development. After these children received the MMR vaccine, the parents claimed they noticed on onset of behavioral symptoms. It was written that there was "loss of acquired skills, including language, together with diarrhea and abdominal pain" (Wakefield, 1998, p. 637). Although many parents believe in Wakefield's article, the article was retracted byThe Lancet.Over a period of time the results of Wakefield's study could not be duplicated.
